Try to follow some sort of coding guidelines such as Naming Conventions(variables, classes,functions ,...) small things but makes a big difference, also read about the best practices of the language you use. as others suggest Robert Martin's Clean code is the best book to read in this topic. here are a few points that will help you: Names: use intention revealing names, If a name requires a comment, then the name doesn't reveal it's intent. don't encode the container type into the name. if names must be different, then they should also mean something different (Avoid noise words product-productInfo-ProductData!). Longer names trump shorter names and any searchable name trumps a constant in code. Pick one word per concept (consistent names). Avid using the same word for 2 purposes. Add meaningful context( by enclosing names in well-named classes, functions, namespaces). class name must be noun or noun phrase. Function name must be verb or verb phrase. FUNCTIONS do one thing (one level of abstraction). The ideal number Function Arguments is Zero(better for readability & testing). Functions should have no side effects(Ex: Change global variables). Avoid output arguments. Extract try/catch blocks out into functions of their own. Error handling is one thing(function that do nothing else). DRY (don't repeat yourself). read about SOLID. More and More when you read the book.
